title: Harvey Weinstein attends event at NY bar, called out by stand-up comedian
text:
CLOSE Comedian Kelly Bachman called out the "elephant in the room" after finding out that Harvey Weinstein was sitting in the crow during her stand-up show. USA TODAY

A comedian called out Harvey Weinstein during a "tense" stand-up show in New York after learning the disgraced film producer was at the comedy event.

Weinstein, who faces sex-crime charges and lawsuits stemming from allegations of sexual misconduct, was at Manhattan's Downtime Bar Wednesday night to watch Actor's Hour, according to photos and videos taken by a fellow attendee.

Stand-up comic Kelly Bachman addressed the "elephant in the room" during her set.

"I'm feeling a little tense … anybody else?" said Bachman, who posted footage of her stand-up performance on social media. "I'm a comic and it's our job to name the elephant in the room. Do we know what that is? Yeah … it's a Freddy Krueger in the room, if you will."

More: Rose McGowan sues Harvey Weinstein, claiming 'diabolical' intimidation plot

She continued, "I didn't know that we have to bring our own mace and rape whistles to Actor's Hour," which is described as an exclusive speak-easy "dedicated to artists."

Bachman was instantly booed for her remark by several audience members. One told the comedian to "shut up."

"Oh, shut up? This kills at group therapy for rape survivors," she said in response. "They love it."

Bachman didn't stop there. She added, "I have been raped, surprisingly by no one in this room. I never got to confront those guys, so just a general (expletive) you to whoever."

In a statement to BuzzFeed News, Weinstein's rep, Juda Engelmayer, said: "I would just point out that accusations are not convictions, and due process is still the foundation of each and every one of our civil rights in this country." (Weinstein has denied all allegations of non-consensual sex.)

USA TODAY reached out to Weinstein's rep for comment.

More: Harvey Weinstein's lawyer says he's a 'sinner,' not a rapist

Harvey Weinstein, center, leaves New York Supreme Court in New York on Dec. 20, 2018. (Photo: Mark Lennihan, AP)

An event patron, Zoe Stuckless, described being kicked out after confronting Weinstein, describing the encounter on Facebook as "one of the most surreal nights of my life."

Stuckless shared a video that showed Weinstein silently sitting in a booth surrounded by an entourage as Stuckless yelled at him.

"Nobody’s going to say anything?" Stuckless said. "I’ll get out of here, that’s fine, I am happy to leave. But nobody’s going to say anything. I am going to stand four feet from a (expletive) rapist and nobody’s going to say anything?"

Stuckless said Weinstein "wasn’t hiding. He came to watch young artists be vulnerable on stage."

Stuckless continued: "In some ways tonight was a horrible, painful reminder of the power a man like Weinstein holds even now. It was a reminder that even in this time of relative awareness it is hypnotically easy to be pulled into a culture of silence."

Downtime Bar appeared to refer to Stuckless as a "heckler" in a statement posted to Facebook Thursday.

"We want to address some concerns about a recent incident at Downtime. A company called Actors Hour rented our bar for a private event, with a guest list all their own. Shortly into the evening, one guest began heckling another, causing a disturbance to everyone in attendance. After several requests to stop were ignored, we kindly asked the heckler to leave."

The statement continued: "Please know that our goal at Downtime is to create an environment where everyone feels welcome. We respect the privacy of our patrons and event partners, and want to ensure that all guests are treated equally, with the same service and respect. In keeping with this goal, we made a decision that would allow the evening to continue as planned."

USA TODAY reached out to Downtime Bar for comment.
